description.narrative: A multi-donor basket fund administered by UNDP to support the electoral cycle during Phase II of the democratic transition in Yemen. Expected key results: 1. Enhanced proper planning and administration of voter registration, the constitutional referendum, and remaining elections, 2. Inclusive electoral legal reform supported, and 3. Increased participation in the electoral process

En multi-donor basked fund administrerad av UNDP med syfte att stödja valprocessen under fas II av den demokratiska transitionen i Jemen. Förväntade resultat är: 1) Stärkt planering av och genomförd väljarregistrering, folkomröstning om konstitutionen, och återstående val 2) Reformering av vallagarna på ett inkluderande sätt, 3) Ökat deltagande av civila samhället, politiska partier mm i valprocessen

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2015Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: The Support to Elections during the Transitional Period phase II (SETP II) was an electoral assistance project in Yemen. It aimed to strenghten electoral administration to conduct fair, open and inclusive electoral events (voter registration, referendum, parliamentary and/or local elections), reform electoral law ensuring the technical needs provided for inclusive and electoral processes, increased stakeholder engagement to encourage voter education, and finally; improve comprehension of the new voter registration processes as well as the roles and responsibilities in electoral processes. The program has been seriously affected by the conflict in Yemen.
Partial achievement was reached regarding a strengthened electoral administration to conduct fair, open and inclusive electoral events as in the procurement of Biometric Voter Registration (BVR) kits and associated software in 2013, and tested in Sana'a. As part of this pilot, Gemalto (the contractor) organized one course on administering BVR kits. Additional planned BVR training activities did not take place and have been cancelled as part of the contract termination due to the project’s closure, which diminished the ability of SCER to fully benefit from the kits without further training investment.
Reform of Electoral Law to ensure that the technical needs provide for inclusive and fair electoral processes was not achieved.
Increased stakeholder engagement to encourage voter education and turnout to ensure fair electoral results was either not achieved although limited activities took place with stakeholders. In addition to this, the SETP II Communications Specialist resigned which led to facing challenges of recruiting a skilled Communications and Outreach Advisor owing to the security situation in the country which discouraged suitable candidates to apply.
There was some partial achievement when it comes to improved comprehension of the new voter registration processes as well as the roles and responsibilities in electoral processes. Based on the contracting of a communication firm a BVR outreach and education campaign was designed. Most of campaign products were completed before the end of SETP II, however: the campaing itself was not conducted.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
